content.title: Understanding the 3-Plate System
content.content:
Safety note: This lesson is for conceptual learning on training rigs. Never open or work on real ceiling roses in a live domestic installation.

**1. What is a Ceiling Rose?**
If you have never seen one, a ceiling rose is two things in one: a **junction point** where several cables join together, and the **connection point** for the lamp holder (the part the light hangs from). It is not just a connector; it is the place where the circuit loops to the next light, which is why it often looks crowded with wires.

**2. What 'Loop-in' Means**
A lighting circuit usually moves from the consumer unit to Light 1, then Light 2, and so on. 'Loop-in' means the main supply is looped from one light point to the next. At each rose, you typically have a cable coming in (supply in), a cable going out (supply to the next light), and a cable going to the switch (the switch drop).

**3. The Three Plates (The Terminal Groups)**
Think of a 3-plate rose as three separate labelled buckets:

1. **Plate A — Neutrals Group:** This is for all neutrals. This includes the Neutral from the supply in, the Neutral to the supply out, and the Neutral wire for the lamp itself. The Neutral is normally **not** switched.

2. **Plate B — Permanent Lives Loop:** This is the 'always live' group. It includes the Live from the supply in, the Live going to the next light, and the Live going down to the switch. This group stays live whether the light is on or off.

3. **Plate C — Switched Live:** This group is specifically for the power returning from the switch. It contains the wire coming back from the switch and the lamp's live connection. This is only live when the switch is **ON**.

**4. The Role of the Switch**
A 1-way switch acts as a bridge. In loop-in wiring, the switch has a feed going down to it (from the Permanent Live group) and a return coming back (to the Switched Live group). The switch controls whether power can jump from the 'always live' group to the lamp.

**5. The Wiring Map**
To keep it simple, remember these roles:
- **Neutrals:** In, Out, Lamp.
- **Permanent Lives:** In, Out, Feed to Switch.
- **Switched Live:** Return from Switch, Lamp Live.
- **Earth (CPC):** All earth wires must be connected together and to the terminal in the rose base.

questions.questionText: What are the two main functions of a ceiling rose?
questions.hint: It joins cables and holds the light.

questions.questionText: Which terminal group stays live even when the light switch is turned off?
questions.hint: It's the group that 'loops' the supply to the next light.

questions.questionText: Is the Neutral wire usually connected to the switch in a standard loop-in circuit?
questions.hint: The switch only interrupts the live path.

questions.questionText: Why is the lamp's live wire kept in a separate terminal from the supply 'Live In' wires?
questions.expectedAnswer: So the switch can control it
questions.hint: If it were in the permanent live group, the light would be on forever.

questions.questionText: In a 3-plate ceiling rose, how many wires are typically found in the Neutral terminal group if the circuit continues to another room?
questions.hint: Neutral in, Neutral out, and Neutral to the lamp.

questions.questionText: Which specific conductor returns from the switch to the ceiling rose?
questions.hint: It's the wire that becomes live only when the switch is flipped.

questions.questionText: What is the name of the wiring method where power goes from rose to rose rather than switch to switch?
Explain why a ceiling rose at the end of a circuit (the last light) has fewer wires than one in the middle of a circuit. Which specific wires would be missing?
questions.expectedAnswer: The 'Supply Out' wires (Live and Neutral) are missing because there is no next light to feed.
questions.hint: Think about the 'Out' part of the loop.

content.title: Spaced Review (from prerequisites)

questions.questionText: According to Ohm's Law, if resistance stays the same but voltage increases, what happens to the current?
questions.hint: V = I x R. If V goes up and R is constant, I must go up.

questions.questionText: What is the primary purpose of a CPC (Circuit Protective Conductor)?
questions.expectedAnswer: To provide a path for fault current to earth

questions.questionText: In a series circuit, what can you say about the current at any point in the loop?
questions.hint: There is only one path for the electrons to follow.

questions.questionText: Before working on any part of an electrical installation, what safety procedure must be followed?
questions.hint: Think about locking off and proving dead.

content.notes: Reviewing Ohm's Law, earthing, series circuits, and safety procedures from Unit 204 basics.
